body.p: This course focuses on the Java Platform, Enterprise Edition (Java EE) for the development of multi-tier applications.
The course is divided up into three main areas; data access, n-tier applications, and asynchronous applications.

ul.li: Data Access - this will cover data access patterns, Java Database Connectivity (JDBC), and the EJB3 Java Persistence API.

N-Tier Applications - will cover data access integration into Web applications, Remote Method Invocation (RMI), Session Beans, Java Naming and Directory Interface (JNDI), Java Transaction API (JTA), Java EE Security, and Enterprise Archives (EARs)
Asynchronous Applications - will cover the Java Message Service (JMS), Message Driven Beans (MDBs), and Timers

body.p: Using modern development tools, commercial persistence providers, and application servers, students will design and implement several significant programming projects using the above mentioned technologies and deploy them to a Java EE environment that they will manage.

ul.li: Prerequisite: 605.481 Distributed Development on the World Wide Web or equivalent.
Strong Java programming skills are assumed.
Students should be prepared to spend between 10-16 hours a week outside of class.

A Servlet/JSP Text
Core Servlets and JavaServer Pages (JSP), 2nd Edition, Marty Hall, 2003, Prentice Hall PTR; ISBN 0130092290

body.p: This course will make heavy use of development tools (Subversion client, Maven 2, JUnit, Log4j, and Eclipse), databases (Hypersonic; comes with JBoss), persistence providers (Hibernate; comes with JBoss), and application servers (JBoss). Students are strongly encouraged to establish a local development environment. Detailed instructions for setup are part of the first exercise (Development Environment Setup).

Much of the material in this course is either new or changing. Some of the referenced texts or the material they cover can be obtained on-line as well as through book stores. The form in which you access this material is up to you. A list of online references can be found on this site. Each lecture will supply a list of references for that technical area.

ul.li: Students will be graded on three projects and quizzes. Projects will be done individually and graded 100 though 0. A quiz, based on sample questions supplied with the project assignment, will be held in the class immediately after a project is due. Quizzes are closed to notes/text. Students not attending a quiz will be required to take a make-up quiz through the college office.

Late projects will be deducted 10pts/week late, starting after the due date/time, with one exception. A student may submit a single project up to 4 days late without receiving approval and still receive complete credit. Students taking advantage of the free first pass should still submit an e-mail to the graders notifying them of their intent.

Projects must be submitted via e-mail to the graders with source code in one zip file with a README. Pre-build artifacts must also be included in the submission. All source code must be written to portably compile in the grader's environment using Maven 2 or Ant.
Class attendance is strongly recommended, but not mandatory. The student is responsible for obtaining any written or oral information covered during their absence.

Collaboration of ideas and approaches are strongly encouraged. You may use partial solutions provided by others as a part of your project submission. However, the bulk usage of another students implementation or project will result in a 0 for the project. There is a difference between sharing ideas/code snippets and turning in someone else's work as your own. When in doubt, document your sources.
